The Global Health Supply Chain Project (GHSCP) was established to ensure a secure, reliable, cost-effective and sustainable supply chain to meet the care and treatment of PLHAs or those affected by HIV/AIDS. In Uganda, GHSCP provides procurement services to serve sites supported by USAID IPs, and working in close coordination with MOH, National Medical Stores and Global Fund Principal Recipients. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.10: Treatment/ARV Drugs. This includes procurement, delivery and in-freight of ARV drugs. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

The Global Health Supply Chain Project (GHSCP) was established to ensure a secure, reliable, cost-effective and sustainable supply chain to meet the care and treatment of PLHAs or those affected by HIV/AIDS. In Uganda, GHSCP provides procurement services to serve sites supported by USAID IPs, and working in close coordination with MOH, National Medical Stores and Global Fund Principal Recipients. In COP16 USG aims to ensure that all private and public sector sites providing HIV/AIDS services have sufficient HIV commodities. GHSCP contributes to GHI principles 3 and 4: “Build sustainability through health systems strengthening” and “Strengthen and leverage key multilateral organizations, global health partnerships and private sector engagement”. With FY16 budget of $118.3M, GHSCP will procure ARVs for private-not-for-profit health facilities supported by USAID and public sector gap fill of ARVs and Cotrimoxazole, lab commodities for CD4 and VL, HIV test kits. GHSCP products, quantities and delivery schedules will be based on supply plans developed for the private and public sectors with MOH. USG is supports and works closely with the Commodity Security group for information sharing and supply monitoring. Joint Medical Store will warehouse and distribute the commodities to USAID-designated private sector sites and National Medical Stores will warehouse and distribute directly to public sector sites. USG will continue to support the Central Public Health Laboratory with both reagents and technical assistance as they move to their new premises. In FY16 GHSCP will establish their presence in the country as SCMS transitions out. Cost efficiency measures already in place include procurement of generics, transport by sea and land wherever possible. No vehicle will be purchased.
